The most powerful case for allegory’s persistence into Romanticism has been made by Paul de Man (following Benjamin), but de Man had no interest in Blake. Frye himself, in an essay written in 1963, modified his case by explaining Blake’s own negative estimate of at least one kind of allegory, wherein the ideas evoked are more important than the manner in which they are represented, potentially leading to a view of poetry as principally “didactic.” Frye here finds that the poetry is best described as “mythopoeic” rather than “allegorical”: see “The Road of Excess
